fi.starck.simplelife
Class LifeSet

java.lang.Object
  java.util.BitSet
      fi.starck.simplelife.LifeSet
All Implemented Interfaces:
LifeLogic, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable
public class LifeSet
extends java.util.BitSet
implements LifeLogic

Game of Life implementation.

Game of Life is cellular automation where each cell is either on or off.

This implementation is finite and noncyclic. The collection of cells is mapped to Java's BitSet and Game of Life rules are added on top of that. Most important part is the step() method, which updates the game state one time step forward.

Author:
Tuomas Starck
See Also:
step(), BitSet, Serialized Form

Constructor Detail

LifeSet

public LifeSet(int w,
               int h)
Create a new set. Minimum width and height of the set is three units. Smaller sets break the algorithm and are also boring.

Parameters:
w - Width of the set.
h - Height of the set.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If requested size is too small.

LifeSet

public LifeSet(int w,
               int h,
               LifeSet old)
Initialize a new set with an existing set.

Parameters:
w - Width of the set.
h - Height of the set.
old - Existing set.
Throws:
java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If old set is smaller then new set.

step

public void step()
One step of cellular automation.

Current set is updated in place according to the rules of Game of Life.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conway%27s_Game_of_Life

Specified by:
step in interface LifeLogic

advanceRow

private int advanceRow(int scanline,
                       int lastline,
                       int iteration)
Advance the row index. Write out buffers and return new row index. If buffers have been emptied, fast forward the row index to current scan line.

Parameters:
scanline - Current scan line.
lastline - Previously scanned line.
iteration - Recursion limit. When this hits zero, buffers should be empty and we can jump forward.
Returns:
New current scan line index.

updateRow

private void updateRow(int row)

Update a row per Game of Life rules.

+ Zero or one neighbours => death by under-population
+ Two neighbours => stays the same
+ Three neighbours => live by reproduction
+ Four or more neighbours => death by overcrowding

Parameters:
row - The index of the row to update.
